item.title: Book Review: ‘The Elements of Power,’ by Nicolas Niarchos
item.description: In a new book, Nicolas Niarchos traces the mineral supply chain for lithium-ion batteries, exposing their considerable human and environmental costs.
item.dc:creator: Peter S. Goodman
item.category: The Elements of Power: A Story of War, Technology, and the Dirtiest Supply Chain on Earth (Book)
item.media:credit: Ashley Gilbertson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cobalt and copper concession in Kisanfu, Democratic Republic of Congo, in 2021.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Crux,’ by Gabriel Tallent
item.description: Gabriel Tallent’s new book, “Crux,” follows high school seniors trying to transcend the hard circumstances of their lives.
item.dc:creator: Bret Anthony Johnston

item.title: 10 Steamy Books Like ‘Heated Rivalry’
item.description: Steamy love stories starring athletes and top-notch yearners will tide you over until your next trip to the cottage.
item.dc:creator: Martine Thompson

item.title: Book Review: ‘Call Me Ishmaelle,’ by Xiaolu Guo
item.description: “Call Me Ishmaelle,” by Xiaolu Guo, audaciously revises Herman Melville’s American classic.
item.dc:creator: William Giraldi

item.title: The 10 Best Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of The New York Times Book Review choose the year’s top fiction and nonfiction.
item.category: The Loneliness of Sonia and Sunny (Book)
There Is No Place for Us: Working and Homeless in America (Book)
Mother Emanuel: Two Centuries of Race, Resistance, and Forgiveness in One Charleston Church (Book)
A Marriage at Sea: A True Story of Love, Obsession, and Shipwreck (Book)
Wild Thing: A Life of Paul Gauguin (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘One Aladdin Two Lamps,’ by Jeanette Winterson
item.description: In her new book, Jeanette Winterson attempts to frame modern-day issues within a classic storytelling text.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Russell Clark

item.title: The Books We’re Looking Forward to This Winter
item.description: Three Book Review editors on what titles they’re most excited about this winter.
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Inset covers: via Knopf; via Viking; via Penguin Press

item.title: Jeff Kinney’s Favorite Funny Books for Young Readers
item.description: The author of the “Diary of a Wimpy Kid” series shares a handful of titles that have helped shape his sense of humor.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Kinney
item.category: The Monster at the End of This Book (Book)

item.title: Books Our Editors Love This Week
item.description: Reading recommendations from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: Miracle Children: Race, Education, and a True Story of False Promises (Book)

item.title: Why Trump Always Thanks You ‘For Your Attention to This Matter’
item.description: How a simple catchphrase sums up the president’s theory of executive power.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott

item.title: Book Review: ‘Fly, Wild Swans,’ by Jung Chang
item.description: Jung Chang’s 1991 memoir, “Wild Swans,” sold millions. Its follow-up delves further into a complex personal and political history.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hilgers
item.category: Fly, Wild Swans: My Mother, Myself and China (Book)
Wild Swans: Three Daughters of China (Book)

item.title: Laura Dave on Her Favorite Books and the Sequel to ‘The Last Thing He Told Me’
item.description: “It’s my comfort book,” she says of the comic novel about a busted marriage. Her own new thriller is a sequel to “The Last Thing He Told Me.”
item.category: The First Time I Saw Him (Book)
The Last Thing He Told Me: A Novel (Book)
The Last Thing He Told Me (TV Program)

item.title: Harper Lee Expanded on Her View of the South in Letters to a Friend
item.description: In decades of correspondence, the author gave her friend, JoBeth McDaniel, a mix of opinions, advice on writing and insight into the impact of the Civil Rights movement.
item.dc:creator: Colin Moynihan
item.media:description: Harper Lee in a photograph taken by her friend Truman Capote. Taken in 1960, it was used on the dust jacket of the first edition of her novel “To Kill a Mockingbird.”

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Summer My Mother Had Green Eyes,’ by Tatiana Tibuleac
item.description: A complicated mother-son relationship reaches a turning point in this coming-of-age novel.
item.dc:creator: Ben Libman
item.category: The Summer My Mother Had Green Eyes (Book)

item.title: How John Kennedy, a G.O.P. Senator, Became a Best-Selling Book Author
item.description: Senator John Kennedy, a garrulous rank-and-file Republican from Louisiana, has struck a nerve with a new book that provides an insider account of Congress and its dysfunction.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:description: Senator John Kennedy’s book on Washington has sold close to half a million copies.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Lost Lambs,’ by Madeline Cash
item.description: A semi-estranged midlife couple and their three precocious daughters form the center of Madeline Cash’s satirical novel, “Lost Lambs.”
item.dc:creator: John Maher

item.title: Book Review: ‘The School of Night,’ by Karl Ove Knausgaard
item.description: The fourth novel in his Morning Star series follows an ambitious young photographer in 1985 London.
item.dc:creator: Randy Boyagoda

item.title: C. Thi Nguyen Explains Our Gamified World in His New Book, ‘The Score’
item.description: In a new book, C. Thi Nguyen looks to his personal passions — from video games to yo-yoing — to illuminate the downside of our increasingly gamified world.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: The Score: How to Stop Playing Somebody Else's Game (Book)
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times

item.title: Karl Ove Knausgaard’s Books: A Guide
item.description: The Norwegian writer is known for his sprawling, brutally candid autofiction and speculative epics. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Adam Dalva
item.category: In the Land of the Cyclops: Essays (Book)
item.media:credit: Photo by Michael Nagle for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: ‘Miracle Children,’ by Katie Benner and Erica L. Green
item.description: “Miracle Children” details how a Louisiana school exploited the demand for stories of Black trauma.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Carey
item.category: TM Landry College Preparatory (Breaux Bridge, La)
Miracle Children: Race, Education, and a True Story of False Promises (Book)

item.title: Book Review: ‘Catapult,’ by Jim Paul
item.description: In “Catapult,” an impulsive project between two friends leads to reflections on human nature and conflict.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.category: Catapult: Harry and I Build a Siege Weapon (Book)
item.media:credit: Florilegius/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Revolutionists,’ by Jason Burke
item.description: In “The Revolutionists,” the Guardian journalist Jason Burke explores how leftist militants gave way to Islamist ones in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.category: The Revolutionists: The Story of the Extremists Who Hijacked the 1970s (Book)
item.media:description: The Palestinian hijacker Leila Khaled in Jordan in 1969.

item.title: Daniel Walker Howe, Historian of Antebellum America, Dies at 88
item.description: In a Pulitzer-winning book, he saw modern America’s origins not so much in one president’s policies as in the sweeping social and technological changes wrought in the years 1815-48.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

item.title: Famed Nigerian Author Blames Death of Toddler Son on Negligent Care
item.description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie is accusing a private hospital in Lagos of administering an overdose of a sedative, prompting an outpouring of complaints by Nigerians about their health care system.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Schaun Champion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie at her home in Maryland in February.

item.title: Erich von Däniken, Who Claimed Aliens Visited Earth, Dies at 90
item.description: His 1968 book, “Chariots of the Gods,” sold hundreds of thousands of copies, but one critic called it a “warped parody of reasoning.”
item.dc:creator: Mike Peed
item.media:description: Mr. von Däniken’s first and most successful books sold hundreds of thousands of copies, and inspired documentaries, comic books and a movie.

item.title: Book Review: ‘The Hitch,’ by Sara Levine
item.description: Sara Levine’s “The Hitch” is a winningly zany portrait of a know-it-all whose beliefs are tested by a supernatural intrusion at a family visit.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs

item.title: Book Review: ‘Strangers,’ by Belle Burden
item.description: Born into exceptional privilege, Belle Burden had it all: love, money, family. Then her marriage fell apart.
item.dc:creator: Alex Kuczynski
item.media:description: The author, far right, with Brooke Astor and her stepmother, Susan Burden, in 1999.

item.title: In “Strangers,” Belle Burden Goes Deep on the End of Her Marriage
item.description: Belle Burden shook off her natural reserve to turn her viral divorce essay into “Strangers,” a bracing memoir.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Victor Llorente for The New York Times
